standfirst: Writer and comedian Stephen Fry discusses the dangers of mass surveillance, calling for a campaign to urge governments around the world to curtail their monitoring of private data. Fry also spoke at a day of action in Shoreditch, east London, on Friday - billed as the biggest privacy event of 2014, with more than 500 people attending. Other speakers included Wikipedia founder Jimmy Wales and Alan Rusbridger, the Guardian editor-in-chief
headline: Stephen Fry on surveillance: there is something squalid and rancid about being spied on - video

standfirst:
The Red Road flats in Glasgow were once home to more than 4,500 people. Now most of the blocks have been emptied and demolition has begun. Jamal, a failed Iraqi Kurdish asylum seeker, lived alone in one block for several months, refusing to move out. If he did, he feared eviction from the UK; if he returned to his homeland, he believed he would be killed

The Bird Man of Red Road has been shortlisted for a Scottish Refugee Council Media Award

http://www.chrisleslie.com
headline: The Bird Man of Red Road: the story behind the Glasgow flats' last resident - video

standfirst: Germany is launching an investigation into whether the NSA hacked the the phone of German Chancellor Angela Merkel. The country's attorney general, Harald Range, says there is not enough evidence to launch a criminal investigation but that preliminary proceedings 'based on initial suspicion' have begun. Range is also looking into wider allegations against both US and the UK surveillance
headline: Investigation into Angela Merkel phone-hacking allegations launched - video

headline: D-day veterans make emotional return to Normandy beaches 70 years on

standfirst: Veterans of the second world war are returning to France for the 70th anniversary of the D-day landings
headline: D-day veterans return to Normandy - in pictures

standfirst: Seventy years on from D-Day, the allied invasion of France, second world war veterans and their families attend a ceremony at Pegasus bridge, Normandy. A mass parachute-drop takes place over nearbvy Ranville, which was the first village to be liberated from German rule during the amphibious landings. Pegasus bridge was a strategic crossing British troops captured just after midnight on D-Day in 1944
headline: D-Day 70th anniversary marked in Ranville, Normandy – video

standfirst: David Cameron pays tribute to those involved in the D-day landings on Friday. The prime minister says he continues to be humbled by what happened. He speaks following a service at Bayeux Cathedral in Normandy, marking the 70th anniversary of the landings, codenamed Operation Neptune, which took place on 6 June 1944
headline: D-day anniversary: David Cameron pays tribute to Normandy landings – video

standfirst: The RAF Red Arrows perform an aerial display over the Solent near Portsmouth as part of the commemorations of the 70th anniversary of D-day. The Hampshire naval port was the departure point for the troops heading to Sword Beach, one of the five beaches targeted in the Normandy landings, codenamed Operation Neptune, and which took place on 6 June 1944
headline: D-day anniversary: Red Arrows perform aerial display over Portsmouth – video

standfirst: Second world war veterans are joined by serving military personnel and schoolchildren to mark Allied operation that helped win the war – but at a terrible cost
headline: D-day 70th anniversary: 'I remember every detail of the landing even now'

standfirst:
Video report explores the background to the D-day landings which helped put an end to the German occupation of western Europe; from the wartime meaning of the word Bigot, to how a ghost army tricked the Germans into defeat in northern France. The 70th anniversary of the amphibious landings has been celebrated on the French and English sides of the channel

Interactive: D-Day landing sites, then and now
headline: D-day anniversary: five facts about the Second World War - video

standfirst:
Weather forecasts by the former naval meteorologist Harold Checketts determined the timing of the Normandy landings
D-day landings scenes in 1944 and now – interactive
headline: D-day anniversary: The weather forecast that paved the way for the Normandy landings

standfirst: On the eve of the 70th anniversary of allied invasion of France, D-day veteran Jock Hutton, 89, parachutes into the same field he landed in 70 years ago. Jock Hutton, 89, jumps from 5,000 feet, strapped to a member of the Red Devils parachute display team, landing just 30ft from the watching Prince of Wales
headline: D-day anniversary: 89-year-old veteran parachutes into Normandy – video

standfirst: Commemorations in Normandy ahead of 70th anniversary of the D-day landings, which saw 156,000 troops from the allied countries including the United Kingdom and the United States join forces to launch an audacious attack on the beaches of Normandy - assaults credited with the eventual defeat of Nazi Germany
headline: D-day anniversary commemorations in France

standfirst: Former naval officer Bernard Jordan returns safely to his nursing home after sneaking out to catch a ferry to Normandy
headline: D-day veteran, 89, who ran off to France for anniversary: 'I'd do it again'

standfirst: Marking the 70th anniversary of the D-day landings in Normandy, veteran Edgar 'Ron' Minton remembers the invasion and reflects on how fortunate he is to live to revisit the site 70 years on. The Normandy landings, codenamed Operation Neptune, took place on 6 June 1944. The largest seaborne invasion in history, D-day began the Allied invasion of German-occupied western Europe and led to the restoration of the French Republic
headline: D-day anniversary: veteran recalls invasion 70 years ago – video

standfirst: Work by allied commander was gift to valet and will join items such as his watch and binoculars to be auctioned
